articles.headline: New Leader in Greece Now Faces Creditors
articles.snippet: The new prime minister’s promise to end austerity, renegotiate Greece’s bailout and reduce the country’s debt burden may be hard to fulfill.
articles.abstract: The new prime minister’s promise to end austerity, renegotiate Greece’s bailout and reduce the country’s debt burden may be hard to fulfill.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As the new Greek prime minister turns to fulfilling his campaign pledge of renegotiating his country’s bailout loans and reducing its staggering debt burden, he may find that Greece’s international creditors will be harder to persuade than the country’s voters.

articles.headline: Shake-Up at Mattel as Barbie Loses Her Appeal
articles.snippet: Christopher Sinclair stepped in as interim chief of the company, which has struggled with its Barbie brand and other traditional toys that have lost their popularity.
articles.abstract: Christopher Sinclair stepped in as interim chief of the company, which has struggled with its Barbie brand and other traditional toys that have lost their popularity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barbie and other traditional toys are having a much tougher time supporting their elderly parent Mattel, a toymaker significantly weakened by stiff competition from small upstarts and by digital distractions aimed at children.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Officer Is Found Guilty in Leak Tied to Times Reporter
articles.snippet: Jeffrey A. Sterling was convicted of espionage on charges that he told a New York Times reporter about a secret operation to disrupt Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey A. Sterling was convicted of espionage on charges that he told a New York Times reporter about a secret operation to disrupt Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeffrey A. Sterling, a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, was convicted of espionage Monday on charges that he told a reporter for The New York Times about a secret operation to disrupt Iran’s nuclear program.

articles.headline: Koch Brothers’ Budget of $889 Million for 2016 Is on Par With Both Parties’ Spending
articles.snippet: The goal, announced at the billionaire brothers’ annual winter retreat, is an unparalleled effort by outside groups to shape a presidential election.
articles.abstract: The goal, announced at the billionaire brothers’ annual winter retreat, is an unparalleled effort by outside groups to shape a presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: The political network overseen by the conservative billionaires Charles G. and David H. Koch plans to spend close to $900 million on the 2016 campaign, an unparalleled effort by coordinated outside groups to shape a presidential election that is already on track to be the most expensive in history.

articles.headline: China’s Other E-Commerce Giant Follows Its Own Path
articles.snippet: Long overshadowed by its rival Alibaba, JD is basing its business on logistics and a promise to cater to shoppers from click to package delivery.
articles.abstract: Long overshadowed by its rival Alibaba, JD is basing its business on logistics and a promise to cater to shoppers from click to package delivery.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Just about every June, on the anniversary of his company’s founding, Richard Liu dons a big motorcycle helmet and red uniform, hops on a three-wheeled electric bike and makes home deliveries for his e-commerce company JD.com.

articles.headline: Helena Morrissey, Aiming at Britain’s Glass Ceilings, Gets Results
articles.snippet: The fund chief executive’s campaign to put women on British boards has succeeded by concentrating on corporate leaders and on company returns.
articles.abstract: The fund chief executive’s campaign to put women on British boards has succeeded by concentrating on corporate leaders and on company returns.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Suggest to Helena Morrissey that she is Britain’s version of Sheryl Sandberg, and she smiles politely.

articles.headline: Investment Riches Built on Subprime Auto Loans to Poor
articles.snippet: A booming business in lending to poor people with bad credit who need cars to get to work is as much about Wall Street’s demand for high returns as it is about used vehicles.
articles.abstract: A booming business in lending to poor people with bad credit who need cars to get to work is as much about Wall Street’s demand for high returns as it is about used vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: The loans were for used Dodges, Nissans and Chevrolets, many with tens of thousands of miles on the odometer, some more than a decade old.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: S.E.C. Has Yet to Set Rule on Tricky Ratio of C.E.O.’s Pay to Workers’
articles.snippet: Chief executives of successful companies may deserve handsome pay packages, but how do you value the contribution of the average worker?
articles.abstract: Chief executives of successful companies may deserve handsome pay packages, but how do you value the contribution of the average worker?
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, we learned that Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, was paid $9.2 million for 2014. Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase made $20 million. The Starbucks chief Howard Schultz took home $21.5 million. And Viacom said that its chief, Philippe Dauman, received $44.3 million.

articles.headline: Saudi Succession Hints at Shift in Foreign Role
articles.snippet: Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, the new deputy crown prince, embodies Saudi Arabia’s shift to a more assertive foreign policy, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, the new deputy crown prince, embodies Saudi Arabia’s shift to a more assertive foreign policy, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, the interior minister of Saudi Arabia, arrived at a meeting of security chiefs from across the Arab world in Marrakesh, Morocco, last March to deliver a call to arms: It was time, he declared, for a concerted effort to eradicate the Muslim Brotherhood, according to two Arab officials briefed on the meeting.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Again for Murdoch, Romney Can Do No Right
articles.snippet: As Mitt Romney considers a 2016 presidential run, he again finds ill will instead of favor from Rupert Murdoch, a reality that has pained and angered Mr. Romney’s allies.
articles.abstract: As Mitt Romney considers a 2016 presidential run, he again finds ill will instead of favor from Rupert Murdoch, a reality that has pained and angered Mr. Romney’s allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The usually grim-faced media mogul practically swooned in his seat. Moments after Jeb Bush delivered what many in the audience described as an unremarkable talk at a conference in Washington, Rupert Murdoch turned to his seatmate, Valerie Jarrett, the White House adviser, to gush over its content and tone.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Michael Barbaro
